questions.question: A vacation home is rented for 100 days and used personally for 20 days. For tax purposes, the property is treated as:

options.A: A personal residence with no rental deductions
options.B: Rental property with proportional expense deductions limited to rental income
options.C: Rental property with full expense deductions
options.D: A personal residence with rental income excluded

questions.explanation: Personal use exceeds greater of 14 days or 10% of rental days (10 days), so deductions are limited. Expenses are allocated between personal and rental, and rental deductions are limited to rental income (no loss).
questions.tip: Vacation home rules: Personal use >14 days or 10% of rental days = limited deductions. Can't generate loss.

questions.question: The $25,000 rental loss allowance is available to taxpayers who:

options.A: Have any rental activity regardless of involvement
options.B: Actively participate in rental real estate and have MAGI below thresholds

questions.explanation: Active participants in rental real estate can deduct up to $25,000 of losses against non-passive income. This phases out $1 for every $2 of MAGI over $100,000, completely eliminated at $150,000 MAGI.
questions.tip: $25K allowance: Active participation + MAGI <$150K. Not same as material participation. Phases out $100K-$150K.

questions.question: Which item is an AMT adjustment that increases alternative minimum taxable income?

options.B: Tax-exempt interest on private activity bonds

questions.explanation: Interest on certain private activity bonds is tax-exempt for regular tax but is a preference item for AMT. Other AMT adjustments include: SALT deduction, accelerated depreciation differences, and ISO exercise spread.
questions.tip: AMT preferences: Private activity bond interest, ISO spread, accelerated depreciation differences.

questions.question: To claim a home office deduction, the space must be used:

options.B: Regularly and exclusively for business
options.D: Only if the taxpayer has no other office

questions.explanation: Home office deduction requires regular and exclusive business use AND either: (1) principal place of business, (2) place to meet clients, or (3) separate structure. Employees lost this deduction under TCJA.
questions.tip: Home office: Regular + exclusive use. Principal place of business OR client meetings OR separate structure.

questions.question: Which distribution from a traditional IRA before age 59½ avoids the 10% early withdrawal penalty?

options.B: Distribution used for qualified higher education expenses
options.C: Distribution to pay credit card debt

questions.explanation: IRA early withdrawal exceptions include: death, disability, substantially equal periodic payments, medical expenses >7.5% AGI, health insurance while unemployed, first-time home ($10K), higher education expenses.
questions.tip: IRA 72(t) exceptions: Death, disability, SEPP, medical, education, first home. Roth: 5-year rule also applies.

questions.question: Section 179 immediate expensing allows a taxpayer to:

options.A: Expense any business asset regardless of cost
options.B: Immediately deduct the cost of qualifying property up to annual limits

questions.explanation: Section 179 allows immediate expensing of qualifying property (tangible personal property, certain real property improvements) up to the annual dollar limit, subject to taxable income limitation and phase-out for total asset purchases.
questions.tip: Section 179: Immediate expensing up to limit. Limited to taxable income. Phases out at high purchase levels.

questions.question: 100% bonus depreciation under TCJA applies to:

options.B: Qualified property placed in service before phase-down, including used property
options.C: Only new property purchased from unrelated parties
options.D: Only property with a useful life over 20 years

questions.explanation: TCJA expanded bonus depreciation to 100% (phasing down after 2022) and extended it to used property for the first time. Applies to property with recovery period of 20 years or less.
questions.tip: Bonus depreciation: 100% (phasing down), includes used property (new under TCJA), 20-year recovery or less.

questions.question: To qualify for the Section 121 home sale exclusion, the taxpayer must:

options.B: Have owned and used the home as a principal residence for 2 of the last 5 years
options.C: Have owned the home for at least 10 years
options.D: Purchase a replacement home within 2 years

questions.explanation: Section 121 excludes up to $250,000 gain ($500,000 MFJ) if the taxpayer owned and used the home as principal residence for at least 2 of 5 years before sale. No age requirement or replacement home needed.
questions.tip: Section 121: 2 years owned + 2 years used (in last 5 years). $250K single, $500K MFJ. No replacement required.

questions.question: An investment in a Qualified Opportunity Zone Fund provides which tax benefit?

options.A: Immediate deduction for the investment amount
options.B: Deferral of capital gains invested, with potential permanent exclusion after 10 years
options.C: Tax credit equal to 20% of investment
options.D: Exemption from all state and local taxes

questions.explanation: QOZ benefits: (1) Deferral of invested capital gains until 2026 or earlier sale, (2) Basis step-up after holding periods, (3) Exclusion of gain on QOF investment if held 10+ years.
questions.tip: QOZ: Defer gains, step-up basis over time, exclude appreciation after 10 years. Invest capital gains within 180 days.

questions.question: Under TCJA, corporate net operating losses may be carried forward:

options.A: For 20 years and offset 100% of taxable income
options.B: Indefinitely but limited to 80% of taxable income

questions.explanation: TCJA: NOLs carry forward indefinitely (no carryback for most NOLs) but are limited to 80% of taxable income. Pre-2018 NOLs followed 2-year back/20-year forward rules.
questions.tip: Post-2017 NOLs: Indefinite carryforward, 80% limit, generally no carryback. Pre-2018 NOLs had different rules.

questions.question: A stock redemption qualifies as substantially disproportionate (exchange treatment) if after the redemption:

options.B: The shareholder owns less than 50% and less than 80% of their prior percentage
options.C: The corporation has fewer total shares outstanding
options.D: The shareholder receives more than their basis

questions.explanation: Substantially disproportionate: (1) <50% of voting after, (2) voting % after < 80% of voting % before, (3) common stock % after < 80% of common % before. Qualifies as exchange (capital gain), not dividend.
questions.tip: Substantially disproportionate: <50% AND <80% of prior percentage. Meets this = exchange treatment.

questions.question: When a corporation completely liquidates, shareholders generally recognize:

options.A: Ordinary income equal to liquidation proceeds
options.B: Gain or loss equal to proceeds minus stock basis (capital treatment)
options.C: No gain or loss until assets are sold
options.D: Dividend income equal to the corporation's E&P

questions.explanation: In complete liquidation, shareholders exchange stock for liquidating distributions. Gain/loss = FMV of property received minus stock basis. Generally capital gain/loss treatment.
questions.tip: Complete liquidation: Exchange treatment for shareholders. Gain = FMV received - Stock basis. Capital character.

questions.question: A 2% S corporation shareholder-employee receiving employer-paid health insurance must:

options.A: Exclude the premiums from all taxation
options.B: Include premiums in W-2 wages, then deduct as self-employment health insurance
options.C: Pay FICA tax on the premiums with no deduction

questions.explanation: >2% S corp shareholder-employees can't exclude health insurance premiums. The corporation deducts the premiums, includes them in the shareholder's W-2, and the shareholder deducts as self-employed health insurance (above-the-line).
questions.tip: >2% S corp shareholder: Health insurance on W-2, then deduct above-the-line (like self-employed).

questions.question: Which event would terminate an S corporation election?

options.B: Transfer of shares to a partnership

questions.explanation: S status terminates when eligibility requirements are violated: exceeding 100 shareholders, having an ineligible shareholder (partnership, corporation, NRA), issuing a second class of stock, or late filing of required forms.
questions.tip: S termination: Ineligible shareholder, >100 shareholders, second class of stock. Careful with trust/entity shareholders!

questions.conceptTested: Effect of partnership liabilities on basis
questions.question: A partner's share of partnership recourse liabilities:

options.A: Has no effect on partner's basis
options.B: Increases the partner's outside basis

questions.explanation: Partnership liabilities increase partners' outside basis because the partner may ultimately be required to contribute capital to pay the debt. Recourse liabilities are allocated to partners who bear economic risk of loss.
questions.tip: Partnership debt increases outside basis. Recourse = who bears risk. Nonrecourse = generally by profit sharing.

questions.question: When a Section 754 election is in effect and a partnership interest is sold, the partnership:

options.B: Adjusts the basis of partnership assets for the purchasing partner
options.C: Recognizes gain on all appreciated assets

questions.explanation: Section 754 allows basis adjustment to partnership assets when interests are transferred or distributions occur. This prevents the new partner from being taxed on built-in gain that existed before they purchased.
questions.tip: 754 election: Adjusts inside basis to reflect purchase price. Prevents double taxation of built-in gain/loss.

questions.question: An executor of an estate is personally liable for:

options.B: Taxes if estate assets are distributed before paying tax liabilities
options.C: Nothing—liability is limited to estate assets

questions.explanation: Executors have personal liability for estate taxes if they distribute assets before ensuring taxes are paid. They should obtain a discharge from personal liability or retain assets sufficient to cover potential tax.
questions.tip: Executor liability: Distribute before paying taxes = personal liability. Get discharge from IRS to protect yourself.

questions.question: The deceased spouse unused exclusion (DSUE) allows:

options.A: Automatic transfer of unused exemption to surviving spouse
options.B: Transfer of unused exemption to surviving spouse if timely election filed
options.C: Carryover of exemption to the estate's beneficiaries

questions.explanation: Portability allows the surviving spouse to use the deceased spouse's unused exemption amount. An election must be made on a timely filed estate tax return (Form 706), even if no tax is due.
questions.tip: Portability: Must elect on timely Form 706. Not automatic! File even if no tax due to preserve DSUE.

questions.question: A gift of a minority interest in a closely held business may qualify for valuation discounts because:

options.A: Minority interests and lack of marketability reduce fair market value
options.B: The IRS always allows a 30% discount
options.D: Discounts apply only to publicly traded stock

questions.explanation: Minority interest discounts (lack of control) and marketability discounts (not easily sold) may reduce FMV for gift tax purposes. These must be supportable by appraisal and are subject to IRS scrutiny.
questions.tip: Valuation discounts: Minority interest, lack of marketability. Supportable by appraisal. IRS often challenges.

questions.question: Before going to Tax Court, a taxpayer can request:

options.A: An automatic abatement of all penalties
options.B: An administrative appeal with the IRS Office of Appeals

questions.explanation: The IRS Office of Appeals provides administrative review before litigation. Appeals officers have settlement authority and can consider hazards of litigation. Most disputes are resolved at Appeals without court.
questions.tip: IRS Appeals: Administrative review before court. Settlement authority. Resolves most disputes.

questions.question: The civil fraud penalty is:

options.B: 75% of the underpayment attributable to fraud

questions.explanation: The civil fraud penalty is 75% of the portion of the underpayment attributable to fraud. The burden of proof is on the IRS to prove fraud by clear and convincing evidence. No statute of limitations for fraud.
questions.tip: Fraud penalty = 75%. IRS must prove fraud. No SOL for fraud. Criminal fraud = separate prosecution.

questions.question: The parol evidence rule prevents:

options.B: Prior or contemporaneous agreements from contradicting a final written contract

questions.explanation: The parol evidence rule excludes evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements that contradict a fully integrated written contract. Exceptions: fraud, mistake, ambiguity, subsequent modifications.
questions.tip: Parol evidence: Can't use prior/contemporaneous evidence to contradict final written contract. Exceptions exist.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 2, the perfect tender rule requires:

options.B: Goods must conform exactly to contract specifications
options.C: Payment must be made before inspection

questions.explanation: Under UCC perfect tender, if goods or delivery fail to conform to the contract in any respect, the buyer may: reject all, accept all, or accept some and reject others. More strict than common law substantial performance.
questions.tip: UCC perfect tender: Exact conformity required. Buyer can reject non-conforming goods. Seller may have right to cure.

questions.question: Apparent authority exists when:

options.A: The agent has actual written authority
options.B: A third party reasonably believes the agent has authority based on principal's conduct
options.C: The agent claims to have authority
options.D: The principal ratifies the transaction after the fact

questions.explanation: Apparent authority arises from the principal's conduct that leads a reasonable third party to believe the agent has authority. The principal is bound even if actual authority was never granted.
questions.tip: Apparent authority: Principal's conduct → Third party's reasonable belief. Binds principal even without actual authority.

questions.question: Courts may pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable when:

options.B: Corporate formalities are ignored and the corporation is used to perpetrate fraud
options.C: The corporation has more than 10 shareholders
options.D: The corporation operates in multiple states

questions.explanation: Veil piercing occurs when: (1) corporate formalities ignored, (2) undercapitalization, (3) commingling of funds, (4) corporation used as alter ego or to perpetrate fraud. Courts look at the totality of circumstances.
questions.tip: Veil piercing: Ignore formalities + undercapitalize + commingle funds + fraud = lose liability protection.

questions.question: Rule 10b-5 under the Securities Exchange Act prohibits:

options.B: Fraud, manipulation, and deception in connection with securities transactions

questions.explanation: Rule 10b-5 is the primary antifraud provision for securities. It prohibits: material misstatements/omissions, manipulative devices, and deceptive practices in connection with the purchase or sale of any security.
questions.tip: 10b-5: Antifraud rule. Material misrepresentation or omission + scienter + in connection with buy/sell.

questions.question: In bankruptcy, which claim generally has priority over general unsecured creditors?

options.B: Administrative expenses of the bankruptcy estate

questions.explanation: Bankruptcy claim priority: (1) Secured claims (to extent of collateral), (2) Priority claims (admin expenses, wages, taxes), (3) General unsecured. Administrative expenses preserve estate value and are paid first.
questions.tip: Bankruptcy priority: Secured → Priority (admin, wages, taxes) → General unsecured → Equity.

questions.question: A surety differs from a guarantor in that a surety:

options.B: Is primarily liable along with the principal debtor

questions.explanation: A surety is primarily liable—the creditor can pursue the surety immediately without first attempting collection from the debtor. A guarantor has secondary liability—creditor must first try to collect from the debtor.
questions.tip: Surety = primary liability (joint with debtor). Guarantor = secondary liability (after debtor defaults).

questions.question: Under Circular 230, written tax advice must not:

options.B: Be based on unreasonable factual or legal assumptions

questions.explanation: Written advice must not: (1) be based on unreasonable factual/legal assumptions, (2) unreasonably rely on client representations, (3) consider relevant facts the practitioner knows or should know, (4) take into account all relevant federal tax issues.
questions.tip: Written advice: No unreasonable assumptions, don't ignore known facts, consider all relevant issues.

questions.question: Which individual may practice before the IRS in all matters?

options.A: Any taxpayer for their own return only
options.B: A CPA, attorney, or enrolled agent
options.D: A registered tax return preparer in all matters

questions.explanation: Full practice rights before IRS: CPAs, attorneys, and enrolled agents. Enrolled actuaries limited to certain matters. Registered tax return preparers have limited rights (returns they prepared, examinations only).
questions.tip: Full IRS practice: CPA, attorney, enrolled agent. Others have limited rights.

questions.question: The kiddie tax applies the parents' marginal tax rate to:

options.B: Net unearned income of children above a threshold

questions.explanation: The kiddie tax applies parents' top marginal rate to net unearned income of children under 19 (or under 24 if full-time students) above a threshold amount. Prevents shifting investment income to children's lower brackets.
questions.tip: Kiddie tax: Unearned income > threshold taxed at parents' rate. Under 19 (or 24 if student).

questions.question: A taxpayer paying foreign income taxes may elect to:

options.A: Take only a credit, never a deduction
options.B: Either take a credit or deduct the taxes, but not both
options.D: Receive a refund from the foreign country

questions.explanation: Taxpayers may elect to either credit or deduct foreign taxes (itemized deduction). The credit is usually more beneficial but is limited to US tax on foreign income. The election applies to all foreign taxes for the year.
questions.tip: Foreign tax: Credit (usually better, limited) OR deduction (no limit but less valuable). Can't do both.

questions.question: The at-risk rules limit deductions to:

options.A: The amount the taxpayer has invested plus recourse borrowings
options.B: The taxpayer's AGI
options.C: 50% of gross income from the activity
options.D: The fair market value of activity assets

questions.explanation: At-risk amount includes: cash invested, adjusted basis of property contributed, and amounts borrowed for which the taxpayer is personally liable (recourse) or has pledged other property. Nonrecourse debt generally not included.
questions.tip: At-risk = cash + property basis + recourse debt. Generally excludes nonrecourse debt. Limits losses.

questions.question: To file a consolidated return, an affiliated group requires:

options.B: A common parent owning at least 80% of vote and value of subsidiaries
options.D: All corporations in the same state

questions.explanation: Affiliated group: Common parent owns directly 80%+ of vote and value of at least one subsidiary, with the group owning 80%+ of all includible corporations. S corps, foreign corps, and certain others excluded.
questions.tip: Consolidated return: 80% vote + 80% value affiliation. All must elect. S corps and foreign corps excluded.

questions.question: An S corporation with C corporation E&P may be subject to excess net passive income tax if passive income exceeds:

options.B: 25% of gross receipts

questions.explanation: If an S corp has accumulated E&P from C years and passive investment income exceeds 25% of gross receipts, a corporate-level tax applies to excess net passive income. Three consecutive years = S termination.
questions.tip: S corp passive income: >25% of receipts + C corp E&P = tax. 3 consecutive years = S termination.
